   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a  80 year old female with severe COPD, diabetes, lung
   cancer, morbid obesity, who presents to ICU s/p ERCP in setting of
   hypoxia and reintubation
   .
   #. Hypoxia/Hypotension
   Differential includes myocardial infarction, aspiration in setting post
   procedure, COPD exacerbation/OSA, early sepsis given ERCP and possible
   bacteremia, pulmonary edema although less likely given chest
   radiograph. Pancreatitis post ERCP causing ARDS is also less likely
   given clinical picture. Also may have had mucus plug and component of
   atelectasis given her body habitus.
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - pan culture blood, urine, sputum
   - will cover with levo/flagyl to cover for pulmonary and biliary
   process
   - add on diff
   - TTE to assess EF and WMO
   - continue to trend cardiac enzymes
   - repeat ECG in AM
   - nebulizer treatments
   - wean down ventilator settings in hope of early extubation, will
   foloow ABG closely and wean sedation in AM to plan for RSBI, patient
   did excellent on PS trial, will rest o/n on AC and plan to switch back
   to PS at 0400 with plan to extubate in AM
   - volume challenge with normal saline for HoTN although suspect this is
   sedation/med related and less likely to be sepsis
   - hold anti-hypertensives
   - hold diuretic overnight
   .
   #. COPD
   - continue nebulizer treatments
   - hold off on steroids
   - outpatient sleep study to assess for OSA
   .
   # Leukocytosis
   Suspect [**12-30**] stress response after ERCP however will cover empirically
   with levo/flagyl overnight. Pan cultured.
   .
   #. Diabetes
   - place on SSI
   .
   #. Lung cancer
   - s/p LLL resection, did not receive any chemo or XRT, this was done in
   [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. FEN
   - NPO
   .
   #. Access:  PIVx2, A-line
   .
   #. PPx: SQ heparin, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   .
   #. Code:  presumed FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

   Patient is a  80 year old female with severe COPD, diabetes, lung

 cardiac enzymes are positive.  Patient
   sedated now and not currently complaining of CP.  EKG does not show ST

   -heparin gtt

   -Add lopressor 5mg IV q 6hrs daily
 convert to po when patient

   off sedation.
   .

 likely due to acute myocardial ischemia and
   diastolic dysfunction causing increasing pulmonary edema.  Possible
   that her epigastric pain was actually referred myocardial ischemia.
   - repeat CXR in AM

   BP control prior to extubation.
   - volume challenge with normal saline for HoTN although suspect this is
   sedation/med related and less likely to be sepsis
   - patient
s only anti-HTN med as outpatient is lasix 40 mg PO daily
   consider adding back lasix if patient
s BP tolerates the Beta-blocker
   as it will help with pulm edema.
   .

   - continue nebulizer treatments
   - hold off on steroids
   - outpatient sleep study to assess for OSA
   .

 Hct steadily declining.
   - send type & screen,

 trending down

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old female with severe COPD, diabetes, lung cancer, and morbid obesity. She is currently in the ICU after undergoing an ERCP procedure and experiencing hypoxia and reintubation. 

The patient has been on arterial line since June 18th, 4:38 PM and was initially tried on PSV (pressure support ventilation) for about an hour last night but was switched to assist-control (A/C) mode to rest overnight for possible extubation today. She has been sedated with propofol. 

This morning, there was a bump in central venous (CV) pressure, so she was started on Hep Drip. The cardiology service was contacted last night and showed EKGs, which they were not too concerned about. They plan to see her this morning and obtain repeat EKG. She is also receiving aspirin per rectum (ASA PR). 

Her lab results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) at 13.7 K/uL, low hemoglobin (Hgb) at 11.4 g/dL, elevated glucose at 136 mg/dL, and abnormal liver function tests with elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT). Her cardiac enzymes (CK, MB, Troponin-T) are positive, indicating cardiac ischemia.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with severe COPD, diabetes, lung cancer, and morbid obesity. She was admitted to the ICU after an ERCP procedure and required reintubation due to hypoxia. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and is currently sedated with propofol. She has shown improvement overnight but experienced a bump in central venous pressure (CE) this morning, so she was started on heparin drip. The cardiologists were not too concerned, but they plan to see her this morning and may start her on hepatitis if they rule in myocardial infarction (MI). Her repeat EKG showed no changes. The patient has allergies to penicillins and had a last dose of antibiotics, metronidazole, at 06:08 AM. She is receiving Heparin Sodium at a rate of 1,100 units/hour and propofol at 50.5 mcg/kg/min. Other ICU medications include famotidine (Pepcid) at 12:00 AM and heparin sodium prophylaxis at 12:00 AM. The patient's medical and family history remain unchanged from admission, except for the addition of a previous MI. Review of systems is unchanged except as noted below.

Physical examination findings include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 71 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 112/62 mmHg to

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Respiratory distress
   24 Hour Events:
   Approx 1 hr after extubation, patient began having respiratory distress
   c/b tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypertensive urgency.  She was not
   hypoxic, but clinically was in acute pulmonary edema.  She was treated
   initially with lisinopril and IV lopressor without improvement in her
   BP.  Widened QRS complexes and ST segment changes were noted on
   telemetry. 12-lead EKG showed evolving ischemia. She was given oxygen,
   aspirin, morphine, additional IV lopressor, and was started on a nitro
   gtt when her BP remained markedly elevated. Nitro was uptitrated with
   gradual resolution of HTN, but the patient remained in resp distress
   and was reintubated.  Cardiology consultation was obtained, but
   ischemia was thought to be rate-related and acute intervention was
   deferred.  She was subsequently treated with heparin gtt, plavix,

   Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w hypoxia,
   reintubated for acute respiratory distress.
   .
   #Respiratory distress
 Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress
   likely produced tachycardia in an attempt to generate CO against an
   elevated afterload. Compromised LV filling due to HR led to acute pulm
   edema and worsening resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic
   diastolic dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation,
   ventilation on current settings.
   -Cont. full vent support
   -Wean FiO2 to maintain PO2 > 60; may uptitrate PEEP to improve
   oxygenation while decr. FiO2
   -Gentle diuresis as BP tolerates
   -TTE today eval for LV dysfunction
   .
   #Demand ischemia
 Reversible ischemic changes on EKG resolved once no
   longer distressed, tachycardic, hypertensive; more c/w demand than ACS.
   No acute intervention warranted, will cont. medical therapy
   -trend troponin to peak
   -heparin gtt, goal PTT 60-80
   -ASA, plavix
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -TTE today to also eval. for WMA, stunned myocardium
   -cards aware of pt
   .
   #. Hypoxia/Hypotension
 likely due to acute myocardial ischemia and
   diastolic dysfunction causing increasing pulmonary edema.  Possible
   that her epigastric pain was actually referred myocardial ischemia.
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - pan culture blood, urine, sputum
   - will d/c abx as patient is afebrile and wbc trending down and low
   suspicion of infection.
   - TTE to assess EF and WMO
   - nebulizer treatments
   - wean sedation to plan for RSBI and PSV.  Will try to optimize HR and
   BP control prior to extubation.
   - volume challenge with normal saline for HoTN although suspect this is
   sedation/med related and less likely to be sepsis
   - patient
s only anti-HTN med as outpatient is lasix 40 mg PO daily
   consider adding back lasix if patient
s BP tolerates the Beta-blocker
   as it will help with pulm edema.
   .
   #. COPD
   - continue nebulizer treatments
   - hold off on steroids
   - outpatient sleep study to assess for OSA
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct steadily declining.
   - send type & screen,
   - recheck around noon and consider transfusing.
   .
   # Leukocytosis
 trending down
   Suspect [**12-30**] stress response after ERCP however will cover empirically
   with levo/flagyl overnight. Pan cultured.
   .
   #. Diabetes
   - place on SSI
   .
   #. Lung cancer
   - s/p LLL resection, did not receive any chemo or XRT, this was done in
   [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. FEN
   - NPO
   .
   #. Access:  PIVx2, A-line
   .
   #. PPx: Hep gtt, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   .
   #. Code:  presumed FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  ICU for now.

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer and previous left lobectomy, who was admitted for respiratory distress. She required reintubation due to acute respiratory distress. The patient also experienced marked hypertension, tachycardia, and hypoxia. She showed signs of acute pulmonary edema and evolving ischemia on EKG. The patient was treated with oxygen, aspirin, morphine, additional IV lopressor, and nitroglycerin, which helped in resolving her hypertension but she remained in respiratory distress. A cardiology consultation was obtained, and she was started on heparin gtt, plavix, aspirin, statin, and low-dose lopressor. The patient has been sedated and intubated. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 88/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. She is on mechanical ventilation support with FiO2 at 60% and PEEP at 8 cmH2O. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low platelet count, elevated troponin T levels, and other abnormal lab values. The patient's assessment and plan include continued full vent support, weaning FiO2 to maintain PO2 > 60, uptitration of PEEP to improve oxygenation while decreasing Fi

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Respiratory distress
   24 Hour Events:
   Approx 1 hr after extubation, patient began having respiratory distress
   c/b tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypertensive urgency to 220
s/150
   She was not hypoxic, but clinically was in acute pulmonary edema.  She
   was treated initially with lisinopril and IV lopressor without
   improvement in her BP.  Widened QRS complexes and ST segment changes
   were noted on telemetry. 12-lead EKG showed evolving ischemia. She was
   given oxygen, aspirin, morphine, additional IV lopressor, and was
   started on a nitro gtt when her BP remained markedly elevated. Nitro
   was uptitrated with gradual resolution of HTN, but the patient remained
   in resp distress and was reintubated.  Cardiology consultation was
   obtained, but ischemia was thought to be rate-related and acute
   intervention was deferred.  She was subsequently treated with heparin
   gtt, plavix, aspirin, statin, and low-dose lopressor.

   Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure s/p ERCP, now with recurrent acute respiratory
   failure following trial of extubation.
   .
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation
 pt had similar event following ERCP.  Marked
   HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia in an
   attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute diastolic
   dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and worsening
   resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV dysfunction
   and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation on current
   settings.
   -Cont. full vent support
   -Wean FiO2 to maintain PO2 > 60
   -Aim to keep volume status even today
   -TTE today eval for LV dysfunction
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .
   #Demand ischemia
 Reversible ischemic changes on EKG resolved once no
   longer distressed, tachycardic, hypertensive; more c/w demand than ACS
   in the setting of presumed underlying CAD; no acute intervention
   warranted, will cont. medical therapy; goal SBP 90, goal HR 65
   -trend troponin to peak
   -heparin gtt, goal PTT 60-80
   -full-dose ASA, plavix
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -TTE today to also eval. for WMA, stunned myocardium
   -cards aware of pt, will likely need elective cath when stable
   .
   #Hypotension
 fluid responsive; likely [**12-30**] sedation
   -IVF bolus, decr. sedation as tolerated if HoTN recurs
   -consider dopa vs. levophed for 1^st line pressor if HoTN refractory to
   IVF
   .
   #Leukocytosis
 Does not appear to be overwhelmingly infected although
   new RLL process invokes PNA vs. pneumonitis.  Also dirty U/A. Likely
   element of reactive leukocytosis.
   -Trend WBC, refrain from treating +GS sputum until culture data
   available
   -f/u Cx data
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct stable, but on systemic AC
   - follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - x-fuse to maintain Hct > 30%
   .
   #ARF
 unclear b/l, has remained 1.3-1.4; may be element of ATN in the
   setting of HoTN vs. pre-renal azotemia
   -monitor Cr
   -urine lytes pending
   .
   #COPD
 Carries the diagnosis, but unclear history; no documented PFT
   in OMR
   - atrovent, albuterol MDI
   - outpatient PFTs
   .
   #DM
   - RISS
   .
   #Sedation
   -versed, fentanyl drip
   .
   #F/E/N
   -volume goal: even
   -start TF
   -replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, calc WNL
   .
   #. Access:  PIV, R IJ, R a-line
   .
   #. PPx: Hep gtt, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   .
   #. Code:  FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Nutren Pulm + beneprotein
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer, who was previously treated with lobectomy and is now dependent on home oxygen. She presented with respiratory distress after extubation and was reintubated due to worsening respiratory status. The patient has a history of respiratory failure, chronic LV dysfunction, and possible subclinical CAD. She also has acute diastolic dysfunction, acute pulmonary edema, and evolving ischemia on EKG. The patient was treated with oxygen, aspirin, morphine, additional IV lopressor, and nitro gtt. She remains in respiratory distress and is currently on full ventilator support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's recurrent acute respiratory failure indicates a potential ongoing complication of respiratory failure.
2. Demand Ischemia: The reversible ischemic changes on EKG suggest reversible demand ischemia due to tachycardia, hypertension, and presumed underlying CAD. Continuous medical therapy is being provided, and further evaluation with TTE is planned.
3. Hypotension: The patient's fluid-responsive hypotension may be related to sedation or other factors. IVF bolus and titration of lopressor are being used to manage this condition.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be reactive or due to a new right lower lobe process. Culture data and follow-up are pending.
5. Anemia:

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress. She underwent a lobectomy and is home oxygen-dependent. The patient's respiratory distress occurred approximately one hour after extubation and was characterized by tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypertensive urgency. She exhibited signs of acute pulmonary edema and was treated with lisinopril, IV lopressor, oxygen, aspirin, morphine, additional IV lopressor, and nitroglycerin. Despite these interventions, the patient remained in respiratory distress and required reintubation. A cardiology consultation was obtained, and the patient was started on heparin, Plavix, aspirin, statin, and low-dose lopressor. The patient also has leukocytosis, anemia, COPD, and diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Distress: The patient experienced respiratory distress after extubation, which required reintubation. This could be due to acute pulmonary edema or compromised lung function. Monitoring and supportive care are necessary to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

2. Hypertension: The patient presented with hypertensive urgency and elevated blood pressure levels. Blood pressure needs to be closely monitored and managed with appropriate antihypertensive medications.

3. Ischemia: The patient showed evolving ischemia on the EKG, which resolved after

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of COPD, diabetes, lung cancer, and morbid obesity. She presents to the ICU after undergoing an ERCP procedure. The patient has experienced hypoxia and required reintubation. She has been diagnosed with NSTEMI/cardiac ischemia, as indicated by positive cardiac enzymes. The patient is currently sedated and not complaining of chest pain. Her EKG does not show any ST changes.

The patient's hypoxia and hypotension are likely due to acute myocardial ischemia and diastolic dysfunction causing increasing pulmonary edema. The epigastric pain experienced by the patient may be referred myocardial ischemia. Repeat CXR in the morning is recommended to assess the patient's condition. Blood, urine, and sputum cultures will be obtained to identify any potential infection. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) will be performed to evaluate the patient's ejection fraction (EF) and wall motion abnormalities (WMO). Nebulizer treatments will continue, and sedation will be weaned off to plan for respiratory system assessment and pressure support ventilation. Optimization of heart rate and blood pressure control prior to extubation is also planned. The patient's only antihypertensive medication as an outpatient is Lasix 40 mg PO daily, and consideration will be given to adding this back if the patient's blood pressure tolerates the beta-blocker, as it will

   Assessment and Plan
   81F with h/o abdominal pain, s/p elective ERCP, unremarkable but
   complicated by reintubatation with another extubation yesterday
   requiring reintubation in the setting of likely flash pulmonary edema.
   the etiology of the flash pulmonary edema remains unclear. likely
   contribution from cardial ischemia given positive troponin and ekg
   changes; unable to tolerate sudden withdrawal of positive pressure
   ventilation. waiting for TTE to elucidate the cause.
   plan:
   -medical managment of cad incling asa, heparin gtt
   -cardiology following, waiting for attending recs esp. re timing of
   cath if needed
   -no sbp today. waiting for additional cardiac work-up
   -new Right lower lobe process, infiltrate of fluid; will monitor for
   signs of infection such as fever, secretion. holding off on antibiotics
   for now
   -once cardiology plan is clarified, will need diuresis, possible
   initiation of nitro gtt prior to the next extubation attempt
   1)Respiratory Failure
patient with clear evolution of acute onset of
   pulmonary edema following extubation.  This is the second time that we
   have seen a sequence of
looking favorable for extubation
evolution of
   significant evidence of tachycardia/tachypnea/hypertension and then
   with likely elevations in LVEDP onset of acute hydrostatic pulmonary
   edema leading to hypoxemic respiratory failure.  In this setting there
   is signficant elevation of troponin and CK consistent with some
   myocardial ischemia and injury.  In addition, patient did have
   epigastic discomfort at the time raising the question of her pain being
   anginal in nature.   Although this is unlikely to represent acute
   coronary syndrome is may well represent significant fixed obstruction
   with signifiant obstruction to flow contributing to recurrent hypoxemic
   respiratory failure.
   -Currently on B-Blocker/Heparin/TNG with goal to diurese
   -Cardiology to consider timing of intervention based on this clinical
   scenario and overall clinical picture
   -Will maintain in A/C and move to wean to PSV when possible.
   -Will not move to SBT in the setting of active ishcemia and plan to
   maintain full support for minimum of 48 hours
   2)Pulmonary Infiltrate
Patient with repeated intubation and although no
   significant aspiration seen at the repeat intubation
aspiration is
   certainly a risk.  She does have a single GPC found in sputum culture.
   Her CXR shows evidence of new right lower lobe opacity with suggestion
   of small effusion.
   -Would favor antibiotics to start in the setting of new infiltrate,
   increased WBC count  should evolution of significant fever or sputum
   production be seen.
   -Will repeat CXR in AM
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure. She has a history of abdominal pain and underwent an elective ERCP, which was unremarkable but complicated by reintubation due to flash pulmonary edema. The cause of the flash pulmonary edema is unclear, but it may be related to cardiac ischemia given positive troponin levels and EKG changes. The patient was unable to tolerate sudden withdrawal of positive pressure ventilation and required reintubation.

The patient's medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. Her current medications include aspirin, heparin, and a beta-blocker. She also has a penicillin allergy.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100.7°F), heart rate of 68 beats per minute, blood pressure of 112/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on endotracheal tube with CPAP. Her central venous pressure is 13 mmHg, and she has received a total of 2,335 mL of intravenous fluids since midnight.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.7 thousand/mm³, hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL, platelet count of 237 thousand/mm³, creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL, blood glucose of 114

   complicated by reintubatation with another extubation yesterday
   requiring reintubation in the setting of likely flash pulmonary edema.
   the etiology of the flash pulmonary edema remains unclear. likely
   contribution from cardial ischemia given positive troponin and ekg
   changes; unable to tolerate sudden withdrawal of positive pressure
   ventilation. waiting for TTE to elucidate the cause.

   cath if needed
   -no sbp today. waiting for additional cardiac work-up
   -new Right lower lobe process, infiltrate of fluid; will monitor for
   signs of infection such as fever, secretion. holding off on antibiotics
   for now

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is an 81-year-old female with a history of abdominal pain, who underwent an elective ERCP procedure.
- The patient experienced respiratory failure and required intubation. Initially extubated, but had to be reintubated due to worsening abdominal pain, respiratory distress, and increasing heart rate and blood pressure.
- The patient showed EKG changes with widening QRS and increasing ST segment, indicating possible cardiac ischemia. These changes resolved with better rate control.
- The patient received multiple medications, including heparin, midazolam, fentanyl, hydralazine, morphine sulfate, famotidine, metoprolol, and regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.
- The patient had a central line placed and received fluid boluses overnight for hypotension.
- The patient was on non-invasive ventilation for a short period but required invasive ventilation due to respiratory distress.
- The patient had a multi-lumen line started and an arterial line placed.
- Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, and abnormal kidney function tests.
- The patient's cardiac enzymes were elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.
- The patient had a new right lower lobe process with fluid infiltrate, which will be monitored for signs of infection.
- The plan includes medical management of CAD, cardiology follow-up, waiting for additional cardiac work-up, monitoring for infection

   Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure s/p ERCP, now with recurrent acute respiratory
   failure following trial of extubation.
   .
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation
 pt had similar event following ERCP.  Marked
   HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia in an
   attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute diastolic
   dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and worsening
   resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV dysfunction
   and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation on current
   settings.
   -Cont. full vent support
   -Wean FiO2 to maintain PO2 > 60
   -Aim to keep volume status even today
   -TTE today eval for LV dysfunction
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .
   #Demand ischemia
 Reversible ischemic changes on EKG resolved once no
   longer distressed, tachycardic, hypertensive; more c/w demand than ACS
   in the setting of presumed underlying CAD; no acute intervention
   warranted, will cont. medical therapy; goal SBP 90, goal HR 65; TTE
   showed preserved bivent fxn but incr. PCWP and mild AS, could not
   exclude WMA
   -heparin gtt, goal PTT 60-80
   -full-dose ASA, plavix
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -diagnostic cath today, may require intervention
   .
   #Hypotension
 fluid responsive; likely [**12-30**] sedation
   -IVF bolus, decr. sedation as tolerated if HoTN recurs
   -consider dopa vs. levophed for 1st line pressor if HoTN refractory to
   IVF
   .
   #Leukocytosis
 Does not appear to be overwhelmingly infected although
   new RLL process invokes PNA vs. pneumonitis.  Also dirty U/A. Likely
   element of reactive leukocytosis.
   -Trend WBC, refrain from treating +GS sputum until culture data
   available
   -f/u Cx data
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct stable, but on systemic AC
   - follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - x-fuse to maintain Hct > 30%
   .
   #ARF
 unclear b/l, has remained 1.3-1.4; may be element of ATN in the
   setting of HoTN vs. pre-renal azotemia
   -monitor Cr
   -urine lytes pending
   .
   #COPD
 Carries the diagnosis, but unclear history; no documented PFT
   in OMR
   - atrovent, albuterol MDI
   - outpatient PFTs
   .
   #DM
   - RISS
   .
   #Sedation
   -versed, fentanyl drip
   .
   #F/E/N
   -volume goal: even
   -start TF
   -replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, calc WNL
   .
   #. Access:  PIV, R IJ, R a-line
   .
   #. PPx: Hep gtt, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   .
   #. Code:  FULL
   .

This event was similar to a previous episode following ERCP. The patient's marked hypertension in the setting of respiratory distress may have produced tachycardia, leading to acute diastolic dysfunction, pulmonary edema, and worsening respiratory status. The patient's chronic LV dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD may be contributing factors.

2. Demand Ischemia: The patient has reversible ischemic changes on EKG that resolved once the distress, tachycardia, and hypertension were addressed. These changes are more consistent with demand ischemia rather than acute coronary syndrome (ACS). No acute intervention is warranted at this time, but the patient will continue medical therapy. The goal is to maintain a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 90 mmHg and heart rate (HR) of 65 beats per minute. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed preserved biventricular function but increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) and mild aortic stenosis. Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer, who underwent a lobectomy and is now dependent on home oxygen. She presented with respiratory failure after an ERCP procedure and again after extubation, suggesting a precipitating event related to abrupt removal of PEEP. The patient has acute pulmonary edema, which could be due to diastolic dysfunction caused by tachycardia. There is evidence of chronic left ventricular dysfunction and/or subclinical coronary artery disease. The patient is currently on full ventilator support, with FiO2 being weaned to maintain a PO2 > 60. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin and cefepime) are being administered due to coag + staph in sputum GS. The patient's volume status should be maintained even today, and there is a benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to maintain positive pressure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has recurrent respiratory failure, likely due to the abrupt removal of PEEP upon extubation, similar to an event following an ERCP procedure. Adequate oxygenation and ventilation are currently being maintained on the ventilator settings.

2. Acute Diastolic Dysfunction: The patient's acute diastolic dysfunction is causing acute pulmonary edema and worsening respiratory status. The elevated afterload due to hypertension may have led to tachycardia in an attempt to generate cardiac output.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer and a previous left lobectomy. She is currently admitted to the ICU due to recurrent acute respiratory failure following a trial of extubation. The patient has a background of chronic lung disease and is dependent on home oxygen. She underwent an ERCP procedure, which may have contributed to her current condition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory failure, likely precipitated by the abrupt removal of PEEP upon extubation. This event is similar to a previous episode following an ERCP procedure. The patient's marked hypertension in the setting of respiratory distress may have caused tachycardia as a compensatory mechanism. Acute diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulmonary edema and worsening respiratory status. Chronic LV dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD could be contributing factors.

2. Demand Ischemia: Reversible ischemic changes on the EKG resolved once the patient was no longer distressed, tachycardic, and hypertensive. This suggests demand ischemia rather than acute coronary syndrome (ACS). However, the patient has a history of presumed underlying CAD, and no acute intervention is warranted at this time.    Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent
   respiratory failure [**12-30**] acute pulmonary edema following a second trial
   of extubation.
   .
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation, similar to the events subsequent to ERCP.
   Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia
   in an attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute
   diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and
   worsening resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV
   dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation
   on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w pneumonitis, does
   have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**]
   -Wean FiO2 to 40% (maintain PO2 >60), incr. RR to 18 to optimize
   oxygenation/ventilation respectively
   -Turn off sedation, PSV trial
   -Lasix gtt to achieve 2-3 L negative today
   -Add low-dose ACEi to improve afterload, diuresis
   -Nitro gtt titrated to SBP 90-100, lopressor titrated to HR 60-65 to
   optimize hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .
   #GPC bacteremia
   -Cont. vanco (day [**2-9**]); d/c cefepime
   -consider changing central line
   -MRSA precautions
   .
   #Demand ischemia
 No proximal coronary stenoses but bivent diastolic
   dysfunction on cath; may have distal, small-vessel disease; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked [**6-19**]; heparin gtt off after 48 hrs
   -ASA 81, statin
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -lisinopril, lopressor as above
   .
   # Anemia
 Hct stable
   - follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - x-fuse to maintain Hct > 30%
   .
   #ARF
 unclear b/l, stable ~1.3; UNa 15 c/w pre-renal azotemia but may
   be element of ATN in the setting of HoTN
   -monitor Cr while diuresing
   .
   #COPD
 Carries the diagnosis, but unclear history; no documented PFT
   in OMR
   - atrovent, albuterol MDI
   - outpatient PFTs
   .
   #DM
   - RISS
   .
   #Sedation
 pt comfortable, pain-free
   -versed, fentanyl boluses PRN to maintain comfort
   .
   #F/E/N
   -volume goal: 2-3L neg (remains +3 L LOS)
   -TF
   -replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, calc WNL
   .

 pt had similar event following ERCP.  Marked
   HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia in an
   attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute diastolic
   dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and worsening
   resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV dysfunction
   and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation on current
   settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w pneumonitis, does have coag +
   staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**]

g prior to cath

   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .

   longer distressed, tachycardic, hypertensive; more c/w demand than ACS
   in the setting of presumed underlying CAD; no acute intervention
   warranted, will cont. medical therapy; goal SBP 90, goal HR 65; TTE

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer, who is dependent on oxygen at home. She was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure following an ERCP procedure. The patient experienced recurrent respiratory failure due to acute pulmonary edema after extubation. The precipitating event was the abrupt removal of PEEP upon extubation, similar to an event that occurred following the ERCP.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, acute diastolic dysfunction, hypertension, and worsening respiratory status. Oxygenation and ventilation are being maintained on current settings. There is an improvement in right lower lobe opacity on the chest X-ray, which indicates pneumonitis. The patient has coagulasive negative staphylococci in her sputum culture.

The plan of care includes continuing full ventilator support, weaning FiO2 to maintain PO2 above 60, continuing vancomycin and cefepime for broad coverage, aiming to keep volume status even, and considering a rapid transition to CPAP following extubation.

Other medical issues include demand ischemia, anemia, acute renal failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus (DM), sedation, fluid/electrolyte management, and infection control measures.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's current condition and previous episodes of respiratory failure indicate a high risk for continued respiratory distress and potential

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of COPD, who was admitted for an elective ERCP procedure. He was intubated before the procedure and subsequently failed two extubations likely due to acute flash pulmonary edema. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of COPD, abdominal pain, and admitted for an elective ERCP. The patient was intubated before the procedures and subsequently failed two extubations likely due to acute flash pulmonary edema, possibly related to ischemia with small vessel disease and stiff ventricles. The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and there are concerns for MRSA PNA/bacteremia. The patient also has a history of CAD, and disposition issues need to be addressed.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's inability to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation increases the risk of respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring and support through mechanical ventilation may be necessary.
2. MRSA PNA/Bacteremia: The presence of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia poses a significant risk. Appropriate antibiotic therapy, including vancomycin, should be continued, and the dosing should be adjusted based on drug levels. Cultures should be repeated to identify the causative organism and guide further treatment.
3. Cardiac Issues: The patient's history of CAD and the development of a new murmur warrant further investigation. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended, and if necessary, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) should be considered to assess cardiac function and structure.
4. Disposition Issues: Given the patient's critical condition, ongoing care in the

   Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent
   respiratory failure [**12-30**] acute pulmonary edema following a second trial
   of extubation.
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation, similar to the events subsequent to ERCP.
   Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia
   in an attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute
   diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and
   worsening resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV
   dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation
   on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w pneumonitis, does
   have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**]
   -Wean FiO2 to 40% (maintain PO2 >60), incr. RR to 18 to optimize
   oxygenation/ventilation respectively
   -Turn off sedation, PSV trial
   -cont Lasix gtt to achieve 2-3 L negative today
   -continue low-dose ACEi to improve afterload, diuresis
   -Nitro gtt titrated to SBP 90-100, lopressor titrated to HR 60-65 to
   optimize hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .
   #GPC bacteremia
   -Cont. vanco (day [**3-12**]); d/c cefepime [**2103-6-22**]
   -central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -MRSA precautions
   #Demand ischemia
 No proximal coronary stenoses but bivent diastolic
   dysfunction on cath; may have distal, small-vessel disease; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked [**6-19**]; heparin gtt off after 48 hrs
   -ASA 81, statin
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -lisinopril, lopressor as above
   # Anemia
 Hct stable
   - follow [**Hospital1 **]
   - x-fuse to maintain Hct > 30%
   #ARF
 unclear b/l, stable ~1.3; UNa 15 c/w pre-renal azotemia but may
   be element of ATN in the setting of HoTN
   -monitor Cr while diuresing
   #COPD
 Carries the diagnosis, but unclear history; no documented PFT
   in OMR
   - atrovent, albuterol MDI
   - outpatient PFTs
   #DM
   - RISS
   #Sedation
 pt comfortable, pain-free
   -versed, fentanyl boluses PRN to maintain comfort
   #F/E/N
   -volume goal: 2-3L neg (remains +3 L LOS)
   -TF
   -replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, calc WNL
   #. Access:  PIV, R a-line, replace CVC
   #. PPx: Hep gtt, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB

The patient also had a heart catheterization which showed normal coronary arteries but biventricular diastolic dysfunction and moderate pulmonary arterial hypertension.

- Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,393 mL of fluids since midnight, with an output of 5,370 mL. The patient also has ongoing losses from TF and drains.
- Oxygenation: The patient requires supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygenation, with a target PO2 of >60.
- Sedation: The patient is currently comfortable and pain-free on versed and fentanyl boluses.
- Renal function

She has had recurrent respiratory failure and is now experiencing acute pulmonary edema. The patient's vital signs show hypertension and tachycardia, and she has been diagnosed with acute diastolic dysfunction. Her oxygen requirement suggests chronic left ventricular dysfunction and/or subclinical coronary artery disease. The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and troponin T, among others. She is currently on multiple medications including furosemide, famotidine, midazolam, and propofol.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of recurrent respiratory failure and acute pulmonary edema puts her at risk for continued respiratory distress and potential respiratory failure.
2. Acute diastolic dysfunction: The patient's elevated blood pressure and tachycardia have led to acute diastolic dysfunction, which can result in decreased cardiac output and further respiratory compromise.
3. Chronic LV dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD: The patient's oxygen requirement suggests chronic left ventricular dysfunction and/or subclinical coronary artery disease, which can lead to ongoing cardiac issues.
4. GPC bacteremia: The patient has a central line infection with gram-positive cocci, which can progress to sepsis if not treated promptly.

   Assessment and Plan
   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent
   respiratory failure [**12-30**] acute pulmonary edema following a second trial
   of extubation.
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation, similar to the events subsequent to ERCP.
   Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia
   in an attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute
   diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and
   worsening resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV
   dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation
   on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w pneumonitis, does
   have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**]
   -Wean FiO2 to 40% (maintain PO2 >60), incr. RR to 18 to optimize
   oxygenation/ventilation respectively
   - Switch sedation from versed/fentanyl to propofol
   -cont Lasix gtt to achieve 3-4 L negative today to optimize extubation
   tomorrow; follow electrolytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -continue low-dose ACEi to improve afterload, diuresis; will consider
   increasing lisinopril from 10mg to 20mg based on blood pressure after
   the sedation is switched to propofol.
   -Will start nitroprusside gtt titrated to SBP 90-100 and lopressor
   titrated to HR 60-65 to optimize hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   .

   -Cont. vanco (day [**4-11**]); d/c cefepime [**2103-6-22**]
   -central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -MRSA precautions
   #Demand ischemia
 No proximal coronary stenoses but bivent diastolic
   dysfunction on cath; may have distal, small-vessel disease; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked [**6-19**]; heparin gtt off after 48 hrs
   -ASA 81, statin
   -titrate lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -lisinopril, lopressor as above
   # Anemia
 Hct stable
   - follow daily
   - x-fuse to maintain Hct > 21%
   #ARF
 unclear b/l, stable ~1.3; UNa 15 c/w pre-renal azotemia but may
   be element of ATN in the setting of HoTN
   -monitor Cr while diuresing
   #COPD
 Carries the diagnosis, but unclear history; no documented PFT
   in OMR
   - atrovent, albuterol MDI
   - outpatient PFTs
   #DM
   - RISS
   #Sedation
 pt comfortable, pain-free

   #F/E/N
   -volume goal: 3-4L neg
   -TF continue for now; will hold after midnight for anticipated
   extubation tomorrow
   -replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, calc WNL

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer who underwent a lobectomy and is dependent on home oxygen. She experienced respiratory failure following extubation after an ERCP procedure and is currently admitted to the ICU with recurrent respiratory failure. The patient's recent events include an unprovoked episode of respiratory distress on the ventilator, breath stacking that resolved with an increase in PEEP to 10, and an episode of hypotension with a CVP of zero after diuresis. The patient has been repleted with magnesium and potassium. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has recurrent respiratory failure, which is a critical condition where the lungs are unable to provide enough oxygen to the body or remove carbon dioxide.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient developed acute pulmonary edema due to diastolic dysfunction, which is a condition where the heart is unable to relax properly during the resting phase of the heartbeat, leading to fluid accumulation in the lungs.
3. Hypotension: The patient experienced an episode of hypotension with a CVP (central venous pressure) of zero, indicating low blood volume or poor blood flow.
4. GPC Bacteremia: The patient has a suspected GPC bacteremia, which is a bloodstream infection caused by Gram-positive bacteria. She is on vancomycin for this condition.
5. Demand Ischemia: The patient may have demand ischemia, which refers to insufficient

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer who has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure. She was previously dependent on oxygen at home and experienced respiratory failure after extubation following an ERCP procedure. She is currently on mechanical ventilation and has recurrent respiratory failure, with acute pulmonary edema after a second trial of extubation. The patient has hypertension and is suspected to have chronic left ventricular dysfunction and/or subclinical coronary artery disease. She is receiving sedation with propofol and has been diuresed with Lasix. The plan is to wean FiO2 to 40% and increase RR to 18 to optimize oxygenation and ventilation. The patient's electrolytes should be followed, and she will be evaluated for extubation tomorrow. She also has a diagnosis of GPC bacteremia, demand ischemia, anemia, acute renal failure, COPD, and diabetes mellitus. Her sedation will be switched from versed/fentanyl to propofol. She is currently comfortable and pain-free.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has recurrent respiratory failure, which is a critical concern in the ICU. Monitoring her oxygenation and ventilation parameters will be crucial to prevent further respiratory compromise.
2. Acute Pulmonary Edema: The patient has developed acute pulmonary edema following extubation, likely due to diastolic dysfunction. Close monitoring of fluid balance and

   80 y/o F h/o lung CA s/p LL lobectomy, home O2-dependent a/w
   respiratory failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent
   respiratory failure [**12-30**] acute pulmonary edema following a second trial
   of extubation.
   #Respiratory failure
 Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal
   of PEEP upon extubation, similar to the events subsequent to ERCP.
   Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress likely produced tachycardia
   in an attempt to generate CO against an elevated afterload. Acute
   diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia led to acute pulm edema and
   worsening resp status.  O2-requirement at b/l invokes chronic LV
   dysfunction and/or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation, ventilation
   on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w pneumonitis, does
   have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**]
   - Switch sedation from versed/fentanyl to propofol
   -cont Lasix gtt to achieve 3-4 L negative today to optimize extubation
   tomorrow; follow electrolytes [**Hospital1 **]
   -continue low-dose ACEi to improve afterload, diuresis; will consider
   increasing lisinopril from 10mg to 20mg based on blood pressure after
   the sedation is switched to propofol.
   -Will start nitroprusside gtt titrated to SBP 90-100 and lopressor
   titrated to HR 60-65 to optimize hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -[**Month (only) 60**] benefit from rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to
   maintain positive pressure
   #GPC bacteremia (1 of 2 bottles---likely contamination)
   -Cont. vanco (day [**5-12**]); d/c cefepime [**2103-6-22**]
   -central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -MRSA precautions
   #Demand ischemia
 No proximal coronary stenoses but bivent diastolic
   dysfunction on cath; may have distal, small-vessel disease; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked [**6-19**]; heparin gtt off after 48 hrs
   -ASA 81, statin

 Hct stable
   - follow daily

 unclear b/l, stable ~1.3; UNa 15 c/w pre-renal azotemia but may

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient is tolerating propofol and remains on a lasix drip with good clinical response. The patient experienced hypotension last night, with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 0 and a net fluid balance of -5000 mL. The hypotension resolved with an intravenous fluid bolus. The patient also has intermittent agitation.

The patient's medical history is significant for COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), advanced, pulmonary edema (diastolic dysfunction), hypertension, restless legs syndrome, and renal function that is preserved with creatinine levels. The patient requires improved blood pressure control, consideration for tracheostomy, optimization of fluid balance, nutritional support, and glycemic control.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature of 37.4 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 104/50 to 171/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light), normal heart sounds, clear breath sounds bilaterally, and warm extremities. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count,

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient's chief complaint is respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated but is tolerating propofol. They are on a lasix drip with good clinical response. The patient experienced hypotension last PM, with CVP being 0 and a net fluid balance of -5000 mL. The hypotension was resolved with an IV fluid bolus. The patient also experienced intermittent agitation.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.4 C (99.4 F), heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/50 mmHg to 171/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's rhythm is sinus rhythm, and their weight is currently 117.8 kg, with a height of 65 inches.

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission, except for hypotension. In terms of respiratory support, the patient is on CPAP/PSV mode with a set tidal volume of 483 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 20 cmH2O, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and an ABG showing pH 7.44, PaCO2 48 mmHg, PaO2 320, and Ve 9.5 L/min.

During the physical examination, the patient appeared comfortable, with no signs of acute distress. The eyes and conjunctiva were normal, with no signs of pallor or scleral edema. The cardiovascular examination revealed a normal PMI, S1 and S2 sounds, and no murmurs or abnormal breath sounds. The abdomen was soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present. The extremities were warm and had trace edema, with no cyanosis or clubbing. The neurologic examination showed the patient to be sedated but responsive to verbal stimuli.

The patient's laboratory values indicate a WBC count of 12.2, Hct of 35%, Plt of 248 K/uL, Cr of 1.3 mg/dL, TCO2 of 27 mmHg, Glucose levels ranging from 93 to 152 mg/dL, and a PT/PTT/INR of 14.7/23.6/1.3. Other lab results are within normal limits.

The assessment and plan include respiratory failure due to multifactorial causes, such as advanced COPD and pulmonary edema. The goal is to work towards another spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and extubation trial if able to remove intravascular volume. The patient also requires improved BP control, consideration of tracheostomy, and optimization of fluid balance. Restless legs syndrome, hypertension, and renal function are also

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. He is on a propofol infusion and lasix drip, which has shown a good clinical response. The patient experienced hypotension, possibly due to a negative net fluid balance of -5000 mL, but it resolved with an IV fluid bolus. The patient also exhibits intermittent agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) and pulmonary edema contribute to respiratory failure. There is a plan to work towards another spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and extubation trial if the patient's intravascular volume is optimized.
2. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may be related to fluid overload. Close monitoring and continued diuresis are recommended to achieve dry weight.
3. Restless Legs Syndrome: Pharmacological treatment should be resumed to manage this condition.
4. Hypertension: Optimizing blood pressure control is necessary. Lisinopril should be changed to captopril, which has a shorter duration of action.
5. Renal Function: The patient's renal function is preserved, but monitoring urine output, BUN (blood urea nitrogen), and creatinine levels is essential.
6. Nutritional Support: The patient requires nutritional support through enteral feeding (Nutren Pulmonary).
7.

   80 yo F with h/o lung CA s/p LUL lobectomy, home O2-dependent, p/w resp
   failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent resp
   failure [**12-30**] acute pulm edema following a second trial of extubation.
   # Resp failure: Failed extubation x 2 with tachycardia and
   hypertension. Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal of PEEP
   upon extubation both times. Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress
   likely produced tachycardia in an attempt to generate CO against an
   elevated afterload. Acute diastolic dysfxn due to tachycardia led to
   acute pulm edema and worsening resp status. O2 requirement at baseline
   invokes chronic LV dysfxn and /or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation
   and ventilation on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w
   pneumonitis; does have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**].
   -          Propofol was weaned off overnight due to hypotension but
   restarted at half the previous rate due to agitation.
   -          Will monitor BP as pt is more awake and aim for afterload
   reduction with captopril.
   -          Attempt extubation today with family at bedside; will
   consider rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to maintain
   positive pressure. Will check with family for confirmation of their
   wishes as pt
s HCP
   -          Continue nitroprusside drip titrated to SBP 90-100 and
   lopressor titrated to HR 60-65 (as tolerated by BP) to optimize
   hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -          Goal I/O even today as pt appears euvolemic to dry today
   clinically; also labs showing high normal Na and high BUN: Cr ratio
   indicating dehydration.
   # GPC bacteremia (1/2 bottles, likely contamination), MRSA + in sputum
   (may be ventilator associated PNA)
   -          Continue Vanco (day [**6-11**]); cefepime was d/c
d [**2103-6-22**]
   -          Central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -          MRSA precautions
   # Demand ischemia
 no proximal coronary stenoses but biventricular
   diastolic dysfxn on cath; may have distal, small vessel dz; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked on [**6-19**]. heparin gtt was d/c
d after 48 hours
   -          Continue ASA 81, statin
   -          Titrate Lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -          Continue Captopril with parameters
   # Anemia, hct stable.
   -          monitor hct daily, transfuse if Hct< 21%
   # Acute renal failure
 unclear baseline, stable at 1.2-1.3. UNa 15 c/w

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer, who underwent a left upper lobe lobectomy and is home oxygen-dependent. She presented with respiratory failure after extubation following an ERCP and now has recurrent respiratory failure, likely due to acute pulmonary edema resulting from abrupt removal of PEEP during extubation. The patient also has hypertension and tachycardia, indicating potential chronic left ventricular dysfunction and/or subclinical coronary artery disease. She requires supplemental oxygen at baseline. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has experienced recurrent respiratory failure, which is a critical concern. It is essential to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Acute pulmonary edema: The patient's acute diastolic dysfunction due to tachycardia has led to acute pulmonary edema. Monitoring and managing fluid balance, blood pressure, and heart function will be crucial.
3. Chronic left ventricular dysfunction: The patient's baseline oxygen requirement suggests chronic left ventricular dysfunction. Close monitoring of cardiac function and consideration of cardiac supportive measures may be necessary.
4. Subclinical coronary artery disease: The patient's hypertension and tachycardia raise concerns about underlying coronary artery disease. Monitoring for signs of ischemia or infarction will be important.
5. Infection: The presence of coagulase-negative staphylococci and streptococcus in the sputum culture suggests a potential infection

 will D/C

 no proximal coronary stenoses but biventricular

d after 48 hours

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has already experienced failed extubation twice, which indicates a high risk of respiratory failure. This could be due to laryngeal edema, which can cause upper airway obstruction.
2. Laryngeal Edema: The patient's previous two extubation attempts failed due to laryngeal edema. This suggests that the patient may be prone to developing laryngeal edema again, which can compromise the airway.
3. Gastrointestinal Infection: The patient has a positive culture for MRSA in her sputum, indicating a potential gastrointestinal infection. This could lead to further complications such as pneumonia or bacteremia.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old female with a history of COPD who was admitted to the ICU for suspected sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has shown signs of improvement, including increased alertness and ability to follow commands.

However, during the afternoon, the patient's condition suddenly deteriorated. She became increasingly tachypneic, developed stridor and increased work of breathing, leading to a drop in oxygen saturation to 88%. Racemic epinephrine and Heliox were given without effect. The patient's blood pressure also increased to the 200s.

Anesthesia was called for re-intubation, who noted the presence of laryngeal edema that made passing a 6.5 tube difficult. The patient's initial settings on the ventilator were A/C 18/550/50/5, and her ABG results showed a pH of 7.46, PaCO2 of 48, HCO3- of 85, and oxygen saturation of 88%.

The patient has a long-standing history of COPD, although her oxygen requirement has been out of proportion to her disease severity. FEV1/FVC is 50-60% of expected. She has required home O2 of 2L since her left upper lobe lobectomy in 2008. COPD had been stable.

The patient has allergies to penicillins and hives

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 65-inch, 102.9 kg male with a history of respiratory failure, presenting in the ICU. The patient's initial blood pressure was in the 90s and was sensitive to propofol, dropping to low 90s. The patient's heart rate was in the 50s. Propofol was weaned off, and captopril and Lopressor were held until the patient's hemodynamics stabilized. The patient's blood pressure has since stabilized in the range of 110-140s. The patient tolerated lower doses of captopril and Lopressor.

The patient was on CPAP 40% 10/8 at 0700, restless, with hypercarbic levels ranging from 50-60s. The patient was oxygenating well and maintaining a pH between 7.42-7.44. At 1600, the patient became more alert, following commands, and nodding appropriately with family present. The patient was extubated and transitioned to [**4-2**] with ABGs within normal limits. The patient tolerated a spontaneous breathing trial well, with sat scores ranging from 92-96 on [**4-2**]. The patient's respiratory rate was between 16-20s, intermittently restless but settled with reassurance. The patient was alert and following commands.

The patient's allergies include penicillins, with a previous adverse reaction

   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo F with h/o lung CA s/p LUL lobectomy, home O2-dependent, p/w resp
   failure following extubation after ERCP, now with recurrent resp
   failure [**12-30**] acute pulm edema following a second trial of extubation.
   # Resp failure: Failed extubation x 2 with tachycardia and
   hypertension. Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal of PEEP
   upon extubation both times. Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress
   likely produced tachycardia in an attempt to generate CO against an
   elevated afterload. Acute diastolic dysfxn due to tachycardia led to
   acute pulm edema and worsening resp status. O2 requirement at baseline
   invokes chronic LV dysfxn and /or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation
   and ventilation on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w
   pneumonitis; does have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**].
   -          Propofol was weaned off overnight due to hypotension but
   restarted at half the previous rate due to agitation.
   -          Will monitor BP as pt is more awake and aim for afterload
   reduction with captopril.
   -          Attempt extubation today with family at bedside; will
   consider rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to maintain
   positive pressure. Will check with family for confirmation of their
   wishes as pt
s HCP
   -          Continue nitroprusside drip titrated to SBP 90-100 and
   lopressor titrated to HR 60-65 (as tolerated by BP) to optimize
   hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -          Goal I/O even today as pt appears euvolemic to dry today
   clinically; also labs showing high normal Na and high BUN: Cr ratio
   indicating dehydration.
   # GPC bacteremia (1/2 bottles, likely contamination), MRSA + in sputum
   (may be ventilator associated PNA)
   -          Continue Vanco (day [**6-11**]); cefepime was d/c
d [**2103-6-22**]
   -          Central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -          MRSA precautions
   # Demand ischemia
 no proximal coronary stenoses but biventricular
   diastolic dysfxn on cath; may have distal, small vessel dz; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked on [**6-19**]. heparin gtt was d/c
d after 48 hours
   -          Continue ASA 81, statin
   -          Titrate Lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -          Continue Captopril with parameters
   # Anemia, hct stable.
   -          monitor hct daily, transfuse if Hct< 21%
   # Acute renal failure
 unclear baseline, stable at 1.2-1.3. UNa 15 c/w
   pre-renal azotemia but may be element of ATN in the setting of HypoTN.
   Cr has been stable despite brisk diuresis
   -          Monitor Cr
   # COPD
 discussed with pt
s outpt pulmonologist, Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 3813**]:[**Telephone/Fax (1) 3814**]. Pt has a long standing diagnosis of COPD with
   additional features of asthma. Last PFTs done in [**8-5**]; FEV1 2.1 (81%
   expected), EFV1/FVC (56% expected). Pt
s O2 requirement has been out of
   proportion to objective data of PFTs. Pt became chronically O2
   dependent after LUL lobectomy in [**8-4**], and is on 2L of oxygen at home.
   Pt also takes Advair 250 [**Hospital1 **], spiriva, and alb PRN. Pt was last seen by
   Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3813**] in [**12-5**], and was stable at that time respiratory wise.
   -          atrovent/albuterol MDI
   -          outpatient follow up with repeat PFTs
   # Mental status: difficult to assess. Occasionally follows commands.
   -          Versed was d/c
d, began propofol, which was stopped last
   night but restarted earlier this AM for comfort.
   -          Continue very low dose propofol to assess alertness.
   # DM
   -          RISS
   # Sedation while on vent
   -          continue propofol, but hold if becomes hypotensive.
   # FEN:
   -          on tube feeds; will hold for pending extubation.
   -          I/O goal today= even
   -          Replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, ca WNL
   # Access: PIV, R A-line, LIJ
   # PPX: SubQ Hep, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   # Code: tentatively DNR/DNI
 will re-check with family when they are
   here
   # Dispo: ICU for now.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer who underwent a left upper lobe lobectomy. She is dependent on oxygen at home and has been admitted to the ICU for elective ERCP. The patient failed extubation twice due to flash pulmonary edema following extubation after ERCP. She is currently intubated and experiencing recurrent respiratory failure with acute pulmonary edema following a second trial of extubation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has failed extubation twice and is currently experiencing recurrent respiratory failure with acute pulmonary edema. This indicates severe respiratory distress and inadequate oxygenation.
2. Acute Pulmonary Edema: The patient has developed acute pulmonary edema on two occasions following extubation. This suggests an underlying cardiac dysfunction or acute lung injury.
3. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): The patient has a long-standing diagnosis of COPD with additional features of asthma. Her oxygen requirement is disproportionate to the objective data of pulmonary function tests (PFTs). She has been chronically dependent on oxygen since her left upper lobe lobectomy.
4. Infectious Complications: The patient has GPC bacteremia (likely contamination) and MRSA-positive sputum (may be ventilator-associated pneumonia). She is on vancomycin and has a central line change. MRSA precautions are in place.
5. Cardiac Dysfunction: The patient has evidence of di

   Assessment and Plan
   80 yo F with h/o lung CA s/p LUL lobectomy, home O2-dependent, p/w resp
   failure following extubation after ERCP, now failed extubation for the
   3^rd time due to laryngeal edema.
   # Resp failure: Failed extubation x 2 with tachycardia and
   hypertension. Suspect precipitating event was abrupt removal of PEEP
   upon extubation both times. Marked HTN in the setting of resp distress
   likely produced tachycardia in an attempt to generate CO against an
   elevated afterload. Acute diastolic dysfxn due to tachycardia led to
   acute pulm edema and worsening resp status. O2 requirement at baseline
   invokes chronic LV dysfxn and /or subclinical CAD. Adequate oxygenation
   and ventilation on current settings. Improved RLL opacity on CXR c/w
   pneumonitis; does have coag + staph in sputum GS from [**6-20**].
   -          Propofol was weaned off overnight due to hypotension but
   restarted at half the previous rate due to agitation.
   -          Will monitor BP as pt is more awake and aim for afterload
   reduction with captopril.
   -          Attempt extubation today with family at bedside; will
   consider rapid transition to CPAP following extubation to maintain
   positive pressure. Will check with family for confirmation of their
   wishes as pt
s HCP
   -          Continue nitroprusside drip titrated to SBP 90-100 and
   lopressor titrated to HR 60-65 (as tolerated by BP) to optimize
   hemodynamics peri-extubation
   -          Goal I/O even today as pt appears euvolemic to dry today
   clinically; also labs showing high normal Na and high BUN: Cr ratio
   indicating dehydration.
   # GPC bacteremia (1/2 bottles, likely contamination), MRSA + in sputum
   (may be ventilator associated PNA)
   -          Continue Vanco (day [**6-11**]); cefepime was d/c
d [**2103-6-22**]
   -          Central line changed [**2103-6-22**]
   -          MRSA precautions
   # Demand ischemia
 no proximal coronary stenoses but biventricular
   diastolic dysfxn on cath; may have distal, small vessel dz; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked on [**6-19**]. heparin gtt was d/c
d after 48 hours
   -          Continue ASA 81, statin
   -          Titrate Lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -          Continue Captopril with parameters
   # Anemia, hct stable.
   -          monitor hct daily, transfuse if Hct< 21%
   # Acute renal failure
 unclear baseline, stable at 1.2-1.3. UNa 15 c/w
   pre-renal azotemia but may be element of ATN in the setting of HypoTN.
   Cr has been stable despite brisk diuresis
   -          Monitor Cr
   # COPD
 discussed with pt
s outpt pulmonologist, Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 3813**]:[**Telephone/Fax (1) 3814**]. Pt has a long standing diagnosis of COPD with
   additional features of asthma. Last PFTs done in [**8-5**]; FEV1 2.1 (81%
   expected), EFV1/FVC (56% expected). Pt
s O2 requirement has been out of
   proportion to objective data of PFTs. Pt became chronically O2
   dependent after LUL lobectomy in [**8-4**], and is on 2L of oxygen at home.
   Pt also takes Advair 250 [**Hospital1 **], spiriva, and alb PRN. Pt was last seen by
   Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3813**] in [**12-5**], and was stable at that time respiratory wise.
   -          atrovent/albuterol MDI
   -          outpatient follow up with repeat PFTs
   # Mental status: difficult to assess. Occasionally follows commands.
   -          Versed was d/c
d, began propofol, which was stopped last
   night but restarted earlier this AM for comfort.
   -          Continue very low dose propofol to assess alertness.
   # DM
   -          RISS
   # Sedation while on vent
   -          continue propofol, but hold if becomes hypotensive.
   # FEN:
   -          on tube feeds; will hold for pending extubation.
   -          I/O goal today= even
   -          Replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, ca WNL
   # Access: PIV, R A-line, LIJ
   # PPX: SubQ Hep, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   # Code: tentatively DNR/DNI
 will re-check with family when they are
   here

Summary:
An 80-year-old female patient with a history of lung cancer surgery, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and oxygen dependency is currently admitted to the ICU. The patient underwent an elective intubation for an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) but experienced flash pulmonary edema after the procedure. She failed extubation twice due to laryngeal edema and recurrent respiratory failure. The patient's oxygen requirement is disproportionate to her disease severity, and she has required home oxygen at a rate of 2L since her left upper lobe lobectomy. She also has a long-standing diagnosis of COPD with additional features of asthma. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, blood pressure of 113/41 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is currently intubated on assist-control ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has failed extubation twice and is currently experiencing recurrent respiratory failure. This could be due to underlying lung disease, acute pulmonary edema, or other factors.
2. Acute Pulmonary Edema: The patient initially experienced flash pulmonary edema after the ERCP procedure and subsequently developed acute pulmonary edema again following extubation. This

Summary:
The patient is an 80-year-old female with a history of lung cancer surgery, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and oxygen dependency. She was initially intubated for an elective endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) but failed extubation twice due to flash pulmonary edema. The patient's condition has been unstable, with fluctuating blood pressure and heart rate. She required sedation and mechanical ventilation. Despite attempts at extubation, she developed laryngeal edema and required reintubation. The patient has a history of COPD exacerbation with increased oxygen requirement. She also has anemia, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus (DM), and a possible demand ischemia with biventricular diastolic dysfunction on cardiac catheterization. The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, indicating an ongoing infection. The plan is to perform a tracheostomy due to scarring from previous tracheostomy attempts. The patient will continue to receive sedation, antibiotics, and supportive care.

Potential medical complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's repeated extubation failures and development of laryngeal edema indicate the risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring and supportive care are necessary.
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has been on tube feeds, which may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. Monitoring for any signs of bleeding

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient has had worsening stridor during the evening, necessitating reintubation with a 6.5 endotracheal tube (ETT) and reinstitution of mechanical ventilation.

The patient's allergies include penicillins, with a last dose of antibiotics being vancomycin on 06/26/2103 at 08:00 AM. Current infusions include propofol at 40 mcg/kg/min. Other ICU medications include famotidine (Pepcid), heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and others such as Decadron, captopril, lopressor, neurontin, citalopram, aspirin, heparin subcutaneously, Lipitor, Pepcid, insulin, and Atrovent inhaler.

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the worsening stridor. Flowsheet data as of 06/26/2103 at 10:45 AM shows vital signs including temperature (Tmax: 37.7°C, Tcurrent: 37.7°C), heart rate (HR: 67 bpm), blood pressure (BP: 102/38 mmHg), respiratory rate (RR: 15 insp/min), oxygen saturation (SpO2: 96%), and heart rhythm (SR). The patient's weight is currently 102.9 kg and height is 65 inches. Central venous pressure (CVP) is 9 mmHg, with total input of 2,507 mL and output of 1,553 mL since 12 AM. Fluid balance is positive at 954 mL.

The patient is receiving respiratory support through an endotracheal tube with a ventilator set at CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode. Vt is set at 550 mL, PS is 5 cmH2O, RR is set at 12, PEEP is 5 cmH2O, FiO2 is 50%, RSBI is 53, PIP is 29 cmH2O, plateau pressure is 20 cmH2O, and SpO2 is 96%. ABG results indicate pH 7.44, PaCO2 50 mmHg, PaO2 156, Ve 8.9 L/min, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 156.

Physical examination reveals the patient to be well-nourished, overweight, and not in acute distress. Eyes/conjunct

   80 yo F with h/o lung CA s/p LUL lobectomy, home O2-dependent, p/w resp
   failure following extubation after ERCP, now failed extubation for the
   3rd time due to laryngeal edema.
   # Resp failure: Failed extubation again due to laryngeal edema. Has h/o
   extubation failure x2 previously with tachycardia and hypertension.
   Suspect the previous two attempts failed due to abrupt removal of PEEP.
   This time, the tachycardia and HTN likely resulted from resp distress
   due to upper airway obstruction with laryngeal edema.
   -          Although unlikely, ACEI could be contributing to laryngeal
   edema
 will D/C
   -          Pt seen by interventional pulmonology for trach placement;
   due to scarring from previous trach, pt will need surgery to place
   trach. General surgery to evaluation pt. Will plan for trach placement
   today or tomorrow, and hold tube feeds for now.
   -          Goal I/O even today and pt appears euvolemic clinically.
   (Lasix gtt stopped yest)
   # GPC bacteremia (1/2 bottles, likely contamination), MRSA + in sputum
   on [**6-20**] (may be ventilator associated PNA). Improved RLL opacity on CXR
   c/w pneumonitis;
   -          Completed a 7-day course of Vancomycine yesterday; will
   discontinue further vanco therapy as RLL infiltrate improved
   radiologically and pt is afebrile. Will re-assess for clinical s/s of
   infxn, ie. Increased sputum production, fever, worsening leukocytosis.
   # Demand ischemia
 no proximal coronary stenoses but biventricular
   diastolic dysfxn on cath; may have distal, small vessel dz; no active
   ischemia, trop peaked on [**6-19**]. heparin gtt was d/c
d after 48 hours
   -          Continue ASA 81, statin
   -          Titrate Lopressor to HR 65 as BP allows
   -          D/C captopril as it may cause laryngeal edema in this pt
   # Anemia, hct stable.
   -          monitor hct daily, transfuse if Hct< 21%
   # Acute renal failure
 Cr 1.4 today, but unclear baseline. UNa 15 c/w
   pre-renal azotemia but may be element of ATN in the setting of HypoTN.
   Lasix drip stopped yesterday.
          -       Pt may have free water deficit, will replete.
   -          Monitor Cr daily
   # COPD
 has been stable per pt
s outside pulmonologist
   -          Continue atrovent/albuterol MDI
   -          outpatient follow up with repeat PFTs
   # DM
   -          RISS
   # Sedation while on vent
   -          continue propofol, but hold if becomes hypotensive.
   # FEN:
   -          on tube feeds; will hold for pending extubation.
   -          I/O goal today= even
   -          Replete lytes to keep K>4, Mg>2, ca WNL
   # Access: PIV, R A-line, LIJ
   # PPX: SubQ Hep, H2 blocker, chlorhexidine, elevate HOB
   # Code: Full code as per discussion with pt and family.
   # Dispo: ICU for now.
